prompt: Because:|I have been out for a walk.|I am feeling better.|Therefore:
Because:|No one has read the letter but John.|No one, who has not read it, knows what it is about.|Therefore:
Because:|Those who are not old like walking.|You and I are young.|Therefore:
Because:|Your course is always honest.|Your course is always the best policy.|Therefore:
Because:|No fat creatures run well.|Some greyhounds run well.|Therefore:
Because:|Some, who deserve the fair, get their deserts.|None but the brave deserve the fair.|Therefore:
Because:|Some Jews are rich.|All Esquimaux are Gentiles.|Therefore:
Because:|Sugar-plums are sweet.|Some sweet things are liked by children.|Therefore:
Because:|John is in the house.|Everybody in the house is ill.|Therefore:
Because:|Umbrellas are useful on a journey.|What is useless on a journey should be left behind.|Therefore:
Because:|Audible music causes vibration in the air.|Inaudible music is not worth paying for.|Therefore:
Because:|Some holidays are rainy.|Rainy days are tiresome.|Therefore:
Because:|No Frenchmen like plumpudding.|All Englishmen like plumpudding.|Therefore:
Because:|No portrait of a lady, that makes her simper or scowl, is satisfactory.|No photograph of a lady ever fails to make her simper or scowl.|Therefore:
Because:|All pale people are phlegmatic.|No one looks poetical unless he is pale.|Therefore:
Because:|No old misers are cheerful.|Some old misers are thin.|Therefore:
Because:|No one, who exercises self-control, fails to keep his temper.|Some judges lose their tempers.|Therefore:
Because:|All pigs are fat.|Nothing that is fed on barley-water is fat.|Therefore:
Because:|All rabbits, that are not greedy, are black.|No old rabbits are free from greediness.|Therefore:
Because:|Some pictures are not first attempts.|No first attempts are really good.|Therefore:
Because:|I never neglect important business.|Your business is unimportant.|Therefore:
Because:|Some lessons are difficult.|What is difficult needs attention.|Therefore:
Because:|All clever people are popular.|All obliging people are popular.|Therefore:
Because:|Thoughtless people do mischief.|No thoughtful person forgets a promise.|Therefore:
Because:|Pigs cannot fly.|Pigs are greedy.|Therefore:
Because:|All soldiers march well.|Some babies are not soldiers.|Therefore:
Because:|No bride-cakes are wholesome.|What is unwholesome should be avoided.|Therefore:
Because:|John is industrious.|No industrious people are unhappy.|Therefore:
Because:|No philosophers are conceited.|Some conceited persons are not gamblers.|Therefore:
Because:|Some excise laws are unjust.|All the laws passed last week relate to excise.|Therefore:
Because:|No military men write poetry.|None of my lodgers are civilians.|Therefore:
Because:|No medicine is nice.|Senna is a medicine.|Therefore:
Because:|Some circulars are not read with pleasure.|No begging-letters are read with pleasure.|Therefore:
Because:|All Britons are brave.|No sailors are cowards.|Therefore:
Because:|Nothing intelligible ever puzzles me.|Logic puzzles me.|Therefore:
Because:|Some pigs are wild.|All pigs are fat.|Therefore:
Because:|All wasps are unfriendly.|All unfriendly creatures are unwelcome.|Therefore:
Because:|No old rabbits are greedy.|All black rabbits are greedy.|Therefore:
Because:|Some eggs are hard-boiled.|No eggs are uncrackable.|Therefore:
Because:|No antelope is ungraceful.|Graceful creatures delight the eye.|Therefore:
Because:|All well-fed canaries sing loud.|No canary is melancholy if it sings loud.|Therefore:
Because:|Some poetry is original.|No original work is producible at will.|Therefore:
Because:|No country, that has been explored, is infested by dragons.|Unexplored countries are fascinating.|Therefore:
Because:|No coals are white.|No niggers are white.|Therefore:
Because:|No bridges are made of sugar.|Some bridges are picturesque.|Therefore:
Because:|No children are patient.|No impatient person can sit still.|Therefore:
Because:|No quadrupeds can whistle.|Some cats are quadrupeds.|Therefore:
Because:|Bores are terrible.|You are a bore.|Therefore:
Because:|Some oysters are silent.|No silent creatures are amusing.|Therefore:
Because:|There are no Jews in the house.|No Gentiles have beards a yard long.|Therefore:
Because:|Canaries, that do not sing loud, are unhappy.|No well-fed canaries fail to sing loud.|Therefore:
Because:|All my sisters have colds.|No one can sing who has a cold.|Therefore:
Because:|All that is made of gold is precious.|Some caskets are precious.|Therefore:
Because:|Some buns are rich.|All buns are nice.|Therefore:
Because:|All my cousins are unjust.|All judges are just.|Therefore:
Because:|Pain is wearisome.|No pain is eagerly wished for.|Therefore:
Because:|All medicine is nasty.|Senna is a medicine.|Therefore:
Because:|Some unkind remarks are annoying.|No critical remarks are kind.|Therefore:
Because:|No tall men have woolly hair.|Niggers have woolly hair.|Therefore:
Because:|All philosophers are logical.|An illogical man is always obstinate.|Therefore:
Because:|John is industrious.|All industrious people are happy.|Therefore:
Because:|These dishes are all well-cooked.|Some dishes are unwholesome if not well-cooked.|Therefore:
Because:|No exciting books suit feverish patients.|Unexciting books make one drowsy.|Therefore:
Because:|No pigs can fly.|All pigs are greedy.|Therefore:
Because:|When a man knows what he’s about, he can detect a sharper.|You and I know what we’re about.|Therefore:
Because:|Some dreams are terrible.|No lambs are terrible.|Therefore:
Because:|No bald creature needs a hairbrush.|No lizards have hair.|Therefore:
Because:|All battles are noisy.|What makes no noise may escape notice.|Therefore:
Because:|All my cousins are unjust.|No judges are unjust.|Therefore:
Because:|All eggs can be cracked.|Some eggs are hard-boiled.|Therefore:
Because:|Prejudiced persons are untrustworthy.|Some unprejudiced persons are disliked.|Therefore:
Because:|No dictatorial person is popular.|She is dictatorial.|Therefore:
Because:|Some bald people wear wigs.|All your children have hair.|Therefore:
Because:|No lobsters are unreasonable.|No reasonable creatures expect impossibilities.|Therefore:
Because:|No nightmare is pleasant.|Unpleasant experiences are not eagerly desired.|Therefore:
Because:|No plumcakes are wholesome.|Some wholesome things are nice.|Therefore:
Because:|Nothing that is nice need be shunned.|Some kinds of jam are nice.|Therefore:
Because:|All ducks waddle.|Nothing that waddles is graceful.|Therefore:
Because:|Sandwiches are satisfying.|Nothing in this dish is unsatisfying.|Therefore:
Because:|No rich man begs in the street.|Those who are not rich should keep accounts.|Therefore:
Because:|Spiders spin webs.|Some creatures, that do not spin webs, are savage.|Therefore:
Because:|Some of these shops are not crowded.|No crowded shops are comfortable.|Therefore:
Because:|Prudent travelers carry plenty of small change.|Imprudent travelers lose their luggage.|Therefore:
Because:|Some geraniums are red.|All these flowers are red.|Therefore:
Because:|None of my cousins are just.|All judges are just.|Therefore:
Because:|No Jews are mad.|All my lodgers are Jews.|Therefore:
Because:|Busy folk are not always talking about their grievances.|Discontented folk are always talking about their grievances.|Therefore:
Because:|None of my cousins are just.|No judges are unjust.|Therefore:
Because:|All teetotalers like sugar.|No nightingale drinks wine.|Therefore:
Because:|No riddles interest me if they can be solved.|All these riddles are insoluble.|Therefore:
Because:|All clear explanations are satisfactory.|Some excuses are unsatisfactory.|Therefore:
Because:|All elderly ladies are talkative.|All good-tempered ladies are talkative.|Therefore:
Because:|No kind deed is unlawful.|What is lawful may be done without scruple.|Therefore:
Because:|No babies are studious.|No babies are good violinists.|Therefore:
Because:|All shillings are round.|All these coins are round.|Therefore:
Because:|No honest men cheat.|No dishonest men are trustworthy.|Therefore:
Because:|None of my boys are clever.|None of my girls are greedy.|Therefore:
Because:|All jokes are meant to amuse.|No Act of Parliament is a joke.|Therefore:
Because:|No eventful tour is ever forgotten.|Uneventful tours are not worth writing a book about.|Therefore:
Because:|All my boys are disobedient.|All my girls are discontented.|Therefore:
Because:|No unexpected pleasure annoys me.|Your visit is an unexpected pleasure.|Therefore:
Because:|No doctors are enthusiastic.|You are enthusiastic.|Therefore:
Because:|Dictionaries are useful.|Useful books are valuable.|Therefore:
Because:|No misers are unselfish.|None but misers save egg-shells.|Therefore:
Because:|Some epicures are ungenerous.|All my uncles are generous.|Therefore:
Because:|Gold is heavy.|Nothing but gold will silence him.|Therefore:
Because:|Some healthy people are fat.|No unhealthy people are strong.|Therefore:
Because:|I saw it in a newspaper.|All newspapers tell lies.|Therefore:
Because:|Some cravats are not artistic.|I admire anything artistic.|Therefore:
Because:|His songs never last an hour.|A song, that lasts an hour, is tedious.|Therefore:
Because:|Some candles give very little light.|Candles are meant to give light.|Therefore:
Because:|All, who are anxious to learn, work hard.|Some of these boys work hard.|Therefore:
Because:|All lions are fierce.|Some lions do not drink coffee.|Therefore:
Because:|No misers are generous.|Some old men are ungenerous.|Therefore:
Because:|No fossil can be crossed in love.|An oyster may be crossed in love.|Therefore:
Because:|All uneducated people are shallow.|Students are all educated.|Therefore:
Because:|All young lambs jump.|No young animals are healthy, unless they jump.|Therefore:
Because:|Ill-managed business is unprofitable.|Railways are never ill-managed.|Therefore:
Because:|No Professors are ignorant.|All ignorant people are vain.|Therefore:
Because:|A prudent man shuns hyænas.|No banker is imprudent.|Therefore:
Because:|All wasps are unfriendly.|No puppies are unfriendly.|Therefore:
Because:|No Jews are honest.|Some Gentiles are rich.|Therefore:
Because:|No idlers win fame.|Some painters are not idle.|Therefore:
Because:|No monkeys are soldiers.|All monkeys are mischievous.|Therefore:
Because:|All these bonbons are chocolate-creams.|All these bonbons are delicious.|Therefore:
Because:|No muffins are wholesome.|All buns are unwholesome.|Therefore:
Because:|Some unauthorised reports are false.|All authorised reports are trustworthy.|Therefore:
Because:|Some pillows are soft.|No pokers are soft.|Therefore:
Because:|Improbable stories are not easily believed.|None of his stories are probable.|Therefore:
Because:|No thieves are honest.|Some dishonest people are found out.|Therefore:
Because:|No muffins are wholesome.|All puffy food is unwholesome.|Therefore:
Because:|No birds, except peacocks, are proud of their tails.|Some birds, that are proud of their tails, cannot sing.|Therefore:
Because:|Warmth relieves pain.|Nothing, that does not relieve pain, is useful in toothache.|Warmth is useful in toothache.|Therefore:
Because:|No bankrupts are rich.|Some merchants are not bankrupts.|Therefore:
Because:|Bores are dreaded.|No bore is ever begged to prolong his visit.|Therefore:
Because:|All wise men walk on their feet.|All unwise men walk on their hands.|Therefore:
Because:|No wheelbarrows are comfortable.|No uncomfortable vehicles are popular.|Therefore:
Because:|No frogs are poetical.|Some ducks are unpoetical.|Therefore:
Because:|No emperors are dentists.|All dentists are dreaded by children.|Therefore:
Because:|Sugar is sweet.|Salt is not sweet.|Therefore:
Because:|Every eagle can fly.|Some pigs cannot fly.|Therefore:
Because:|Babies are illogical.|Nobody is despised who can manage a crocodile.|Illogical persons are despised.|Therefore:
Because:|My saucepans are the only things I have that are made of tin.|I find all your presents very useful.|None of my saucepans are of the slightest use.|Therefore:
Because:|No potatoes of mine, that are new, have been boiled.|All my potatoes in this dish are fit to eat.|No unboiled potatoes of mine are fit to eat.|Therefore:
Because:|There are no Jews in the kitchen.|No Gentiles say shpoonj.|My servants are all in the kitchen.|Therefore:
Because:|No ducks waltz.|No officers ever decline to waltz.|All my poultry are ducks.|Therefore:
Because:|Every one who is sane can do Logic.|No lunatics are fit to serve on a jury.|None of your sons can do Logic.|Therefore:
Because:|There are no pencils of mine in this box.|No sugar-plums of mine are cigars.|The whole of my property, that is not in this box, consists of cigars.|Therefore:
Because:|No experienced person is incompetent.|Jenkins is always blundering.|No competent person is always blundering.|Therefore:
Because:|No terriers wander among the signs of the zodiac.|Nothing, that does not wander among the signs of the zodiac, is a comet.|Nothing but a terrier has a curly tail.|Therefore:
Because:|No one takes in the Times, unless he is well-educated.|No hedge-hogs can read.|Those who cannot read are not well-educated.|Therefore:
Because:|All puddings are nice.|This dish is a pudding.|No nice things are wholesome.|Therefore:

Because:|My gardener is well worth listening to on military subjects.|No one can remember the battle of Waterloo, unless he is very old.|Nobody is really worth listening to on military subjects, unless he can remember the battle of Waterloo.|Therefore:
Because:|All humming-birds are richly coloured.|No large birds live on honey.|Birds that do not live on honey are dull in colour.|Therefore:
Because:|No Gentiles have hooked noses.|A man who is a good hand at a bargain always makes money.|No Jew is ever a bad hand at a bargain.|Therefore:

Because:|All ducks in this village, that are branded ‘B,’ belong to Mrs. Bond.|Ducks in this village never wear lace collars, unless they are branded ‘B’.|Mrs. Bond has no gray ducks in this village.|Therefore:
Because:|All the old articles in this cupboard are cracked.|No jug in this cupboard is new.|Nothing in this cupboard, that is cracked, will hold water.|Therefore:
Because:|All unripe fruit is unwholesome.|All these apples are wholesome.|No fruit, grown in the shade, is ripe.|Therefore:

Because:|Puppies, that will not lie still, are always grateful for the loan of a skipping-rope.|A lame puppy would not say thank you if you offered to lend it a skipping-rope.|None but lame puppies ever care to do worsted-work.|Therefore:

Because:|No name in this list is unsuitable for the hero of a romance.|Names beginning with a vowel are always melodious.|No name is suitable for the hero of a romance, if it begins with a consonant.|Therefore:
Because:|All members of the House of Commons have perfect self-command.|No M.P., who wears a coronet, should ride in a donkey-race.|All members of the House of Lords wear coronets.|Therefore:

Because:|No goods in this shop, that have been bought and paid for, are still on sale.|None of the goods may be carried away, unless labeled sold.|None of the goods are labeled sold, unless they have been bought and paid for.|Therefore:

Because:|No acrobatic feats, that are not announced in the bills of a circus, are ever attempted there.|No acrobatic feat is possible, if it involves turning a quadruple somersault.|No impossible acrobatic feat is ever announced in a circus bill.|Therefore:

Because:|Nobody, who really appreciates Beethoven, fails to keep silence while the Moonlight-Sonata is being played.|Guinea-pigs are hopelessly ignorant of music.|No one, who is hopelessly ignorant of music, ever keeps silence while the Moonlight-Sonata is being played.|Therefore:
Because:|Coloured flowers are always scented.|I dislike flowers that are not grown in the open air.|No flowers grown in the open air are colourless.|Therefore:
Because:|Showy talkers think too much of themselves.|No really well-informed people are bad company.|People who think too much of themselves are not good company.|Therefore:
Because:|No boys under 12 are admitted to this school as boarders.|All the industrious boys have red hair.|None of the day-boys learn Greek.|None but those under 12 are idle.|Therefore:

Because:|The only articles of food, that my doctor allows me, are such as are not very rich.|Nothing that agrees with me is unsuitable for supper.|Wedding-cake is always very rich.|My doctor allows me all articles of food that are suitable for supper.|Therefore:

Because:|No discussions in our Debating-Club are likely to rouse the British Lion, so long as they are checked when they become too noisy.|Discussions, unwisely conducted, endanger the peacefulness of our Debating-Club.|Discussions, that go on while Tomkins is in the Chair, are likely to rouse the British Lion.|Discussions in our Debating-Club, when wisely conducted, are always checked when they become too noisy.|Therefore:
Because:|All my sons are slim.|No child of mine is healthy who takes no exercise.|All gluttons, who are children of mine, are fat.|No daughter of mine takes any exercise.|Therefore:

Because:|Things sold in the street are of no great value.|Nothing but rubbish can be had for a song.|Eggs of the Great Auk are very valuable.|It is only what is sold in the street that is really rubbish.|Therefore:

Because:|No books sold here have gilt edges, except what are in the front shop.|All the authorised editions have red labels.|All the books with red labels are priced at 5s. and upwards.|None but authorised editions are ever placed in the front shop.|Therefore:

Because:|Remedies for bleeding, which fail to check it, are a mockery.|Tincture of Calendula is not to be despised.|Remedies, which will check the bleeding when you cut your finger, are useful.|All mock remedies for bleeding are despicable.|Therefore:

Because:|None of the unnoticed things, met with at sea, are mermaids.|Things entered in the log, as met with at sea, are sure to be worth remembering.|I have never met with anything worth remembering, when on a voyage.|Things met with at sea, that are noticed, are sure to be recorded in the log.|Therefore:

Because:|The only books in this library, that I do not recommend for reading, are unhealthy in tone.|The bound books are all well-written.|All the romances are healthy in tone.|I do not recommend you to read any of the unbound books.|Therefore:

Because:|No birds, except ostriches, are 9 feet high.|There are no birds in this aviary that belong to any one but me.|No ostrich lives on mince-pies.|I have no birds less than 9 feet high.|Therefore:

Because:|A plum-pudding, that is not really solid, is mere porridge.|Every plum-pudding, served at my table, has been boiled in a cloth.|A plum-pudding that is mere porridge is indistinguishable from soup.|No plum-puddings are really solid, except what are served at my table.|Therefore:

Because:|No interesting poems are unpopular among people of real taste.|No modern poetry is free from affectation.|All your poems are on the subject of soap-bubbles.|No affected poetry is popular among people of real taste.|No ancient poem is on the subject of soap-bubbles.|Therefore:

Because:|All the fruit at this Show, that fails to get a prize, is the property of the Committee.|None of my peaches have got prizes.|None of the fruit, sold off in the evening, is unripe.|None of the ripe fruit has been grown in a hot-house.|All fruit, that belongs to the Committee, is sold off in the evening.|Therefore:

Because:|Promise-breakers are untrustworthy.|Wine-drinkers are very communicative.|A man who keeps his promises is honest.|No teetotalers are pawnbrokers.|One can always trust a very communicative person.|Therefore:

Because:|No kitten, that loves fish, is unteachable.|No kitten without a tail will play with a gorilla.|Kittens with whiskers always love fish.|No teachable kitten has green eyes.|No kittens have tails unless they have whiskers.|Therefore:

Because:|All the Eton men in this College play cricket.|None but the Scholars dine at the higher table.|None of the cricketers row.|My friends in this College all come from Eton.|All the Scholars are rowing-men.|Therefore:

Because:|There is no box of mine here that I dare open.|My writing-desk is made of rose-wood.|All my boxes are painted, except what are here.|There is no box of mine that I dare not open, unless it is full of live scorpions.|All my rose-wood boxes are unpainted.|Therefore:

Because:|Gentiles have no objection to pork.|Nobody who admires pigsties ever reads Hogg’s poems.|No Mandarin knows Hebrew.|Every one, who does not object to pork, admires pigsties.|No Jew is ignorant of Hebrew.|Therefore:

Because:|All writers, who understand human nature, are clever.|No one is a true poet unless he can stir the hearts of men.|Shakespeare wrote Hamlet.|No writer, who does not understand human nature, can stir the hearts of men.|None but a true poet could have written Hamlet..|Therefore:

Because:|I despise anything that cannot be used as a bridge.|Everything, that is worth writing an ode to, would be a welcome gift to me.|A rainbow will not bear the weight of a wheel-barrow.|Whatever can be used as a bridge will bear the weight of a wheel-barrow.|I would not take, as a gift, a thing that I despise.|Therefore:

Because:|When I work a Logic-example without grumbling, you may be sure it is one that I can understand.|These Soriteses are not arranged in regular order, like the examples I am used to.|No easy example ever make my head ache.|I ca’n’t understand examples that are not arranged in regular order, like those I am used to.|I never grumble at an example, unless it gives me a headache.|Therefore:

Because:|Every idea of mine, that cannot be expressed as a Syllogism, is really ridiculous.|None of my ideas about Bath-buns are worth writing down.|No idea of mine, that fails to come true, can be expressed as a Syllogism.|I never have any really ridiculous idea, that I do not at once refer to my solicitor.|My dreams are all about Bath-buns.|I never refer any idea of mine to my solicitor, unless it is worth writing down.|Therefore:

Because:|None of the pictures here, except the battle-pieces, are valuable.|None of the unframed ones are varnished.|All the battle-pieces are painted in oils.|All those that have been sold are valuable.|All the English ones are varnished.|All those in frames have been sold.|Therefore:

Because:|Animals, that do not kick, are always unexcitable.|Donkeys have no horns.|A buffalo can always toss one over a gate.|No animals that kick are easy to swallow.|No hornless animal can toss one over a gate.|All animals are excitable, except buffaloes.|Therefore:

Because:|No one, who is going to a party, ever fails to brush his hair.|No one looks fascinating, if he is untidy.|Opium-eaters have no self-command.|Every one, who has brushed his hair, looks fascinating.|No one wears white kid gloves, unless he is going to a party.|A man is always untidy, if he has no self-command.|Therefore:

Because:|No husband, who is always giving his wife new dresses, can be a cross-grained man.|A methodical husband always comes home for his tea.|No one, who hangs up his hat on the gas-jet, can be a man that is kept in proper order by his wife.|A good husband is always giving his wife new dresses.|No husband can fail to be cross-grained, if his wife does not keep him in proper order.|An unmethodical husband always hangs up his hat on the gas-jet.|Therefore:

Because:|Everything, not absolutely ugly, may be kept in a drawing-room.|Nothing, that is encrusted with salt, is ever quite dry.|Nothing should be kept in a drawing-room, unless it is free from damp.|Bathing-machines are always kept near the sea.|Nothing, that is made of mother-of-pearl, can be absolutely ugly.|Whatever is kept near the sea gets encrusted with salt.|Therefore:

Because:|I call no day unlucky, when Robinson is civil to me.|Wednesdays are always cloudy.|When people take umbrellas, the day never turns out fine.|The only days when Robinson is uncivil to me are Wednesdays.|Everybody takes his umbrella with him when it is raining.|My lucky days always turn out fine.|Therefore:

Because:|No shark ever doubts that it is well fitted out.|A fish, that cannot dance a minuet, is contemptible.|No fish is quite certain that it is well fitted out, unless it has three rows of teeth.|All fishes, except sharks, are kind to children.|No heavy fish can dance a minuet.|A fish with three rows of teeth is not to be despised.|Therefore:

Because:|All the human race, except my footmen, have a certain amount of common-sense.|No one, who lives on barley-sugar, can be anything but a mere baby.|None but a hop-scotch player knows what real happiness is.|No mere baby has a grain of common sense.|No engine-driver ever plays hop-scotch.|No footman of mine is ignorant of what true happiness is.|Therefore:

Because:|I trust every animal that belongs to me.|Dogs gnaw bones.|I admit no animals into my study, unless they will beg when told to do so.|All the animals in the yard are mine.|I admit every animal, that I trust, into my study.|The only animals, that are really willing to beg when told to do so, are dogs.|Therefore:

Because:|Animals are always mortally offended if I fail to notice them.|The only animals that belong to me are in that field.|No animal can guess a conundrum, unless it has been properly trained in a Board-School.|None of the animals in that field are badgers.|When an animal is mortally offended, it always rushes about wildly and howls.|I never notice any animal, unless it belongs to me.|No animal, that has been properly trained in a Board-School, ever rushes about wildly and howls.|Therefore:

Because:|I never put a cheque, received by me, on that file, unless I am anxious about it.|All the cheques received by me, that are not marked with a cross, are payable to bearer.|None of them are ever brought back to me, unless they have been dishonoured at the Bank.|All of them, that are marked with a cross, are for amounts of over £100.|All of them, that are not on that file, are marked not negotiable.|No cheque of yours, received by me, has ever been dishonoured.|I am never anxious about a cheque, received by me, unless it should happen to be brought back to me.|None of the cheques received by me, that are marked not negotiable, are for amounts of over £100.|Therefore:

Because:|All the dated letters in this room are written on blue paper.|None of them are in black ink, except those that are written in the third person.|I have not filed any of them that I can read.|None of them, that are written on one sheet, are undated.|All of them, that are not crossed, are in black ink.|All of them, written by Brown, begin with Dear Sir.|All of them, written on blue paper, are filed.|None of them, written on more than one sheet, are crossed.|None of them, that begin with Dear Sir, are written in the third person.|Therefore:

Because:|The only animals in this house are cats.|Every animal is suitable for a pet, that loves to gaze at the moon.|When I detest an animal, I avoid it.|No animals are carnivorous, unless they prowl at night.|No cats fails to kill mice.|No animals ever take to me, except what are in this house.|Kangaroos are not suitable for pets.|None but carnivora kill mice.|I detest animals that do not take to me.|Animals, that prowl at night, always love to gaze at the moon.|Therefore:
